description.narrative: Bidra till ökat användande för ICT i demokratisering och mänskliga rättigheter i Östafrika, samt stärka det östafrikanska nätverket för ICT i demokrati och mänskliga rättigheter.
Increased use of ICT in democratization and human rights in East Africa. - Strenghtening of the East Adfrican network for ICT democracy and human rights network.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Together with relevant stakeholders, the network promotes increased citizens participation in governance and democratic processes, and promotes the realization of human rights and improved transparency and accountability of governments through the use of ICT. The project has been exposed to a changing ICT landscape in East Africa, including growing adoption and usage of ICT by citizens, government and the private sector, alongside increasing threats to the potential of technology to advance livelihoods, diversity and inclusion, and democratic governance. Most of the activities and results have been according to plan. Some planned activities whereaffected by the increase in restriction on civic space, for example, in Tanzania where CIPESAs executive director was detained and deported in connection to attending an event. Nonetheless, despite increasing challenges such as shrinking civic space, a changingICT landscape in East Africa affecting all three implementation countries, and not the least the Covid-19 pandemic, the project has worked well towards its objectives and achieved goodresults and according to the report, most targets have been met or surpassed. Examples of activities and key results achieved include (from last annual report August 2019): - 1,300 individuals in Uganda benefited from skills building for the use of ICT forengagement in governance and social accountability as well as legal literacy and digitalsafety. The target group included journalists, bloggers, youth groups, local governmentofficials and citizens journalists. - 1,536 officials have been trained in the health, infrastructure and education sectors. - The average number of reports received via the toll free MML platform increased to 700 while the M-Omulimisa SMS platform received 717 reports on the water, health, infrastructure and education services, with a recorded resolution and conclusion rate of 97%. - 26 local, district and national duty bearers and policy makers in Western Uganda attended monthly accountability meetings in 2018, an increase from the average 10 in 2017. - The project has worked to raise visibility of the service delivery, access to ICT and participation in governance concerns of persons with disabilities. In Northern Uganda, emphasis was put on accessibility of health facilities. At national level in Uganda, policy advocacy and engagement have included submissions and presentations on promoting meaningful digital accessibility for persons with disabilities. - 860 civil society organisations, journalists, paralegals, grassroots human rights networks,youth groups and local government officials in Kenya and Tanzania benefitted from skills building in human rights advocacy, monitoring and reporting through ICT. Beneficiaries have reported an increased confidence in engaging with duty bearers and governance processes to demand accountability and transparency.- The SMS based platforms for reporting human rights violations in Kenya and Tanzania were complemented with legal aid clinics to support complainants to prepare court documents for verified and investigated cases. In Tanzania, the SMS for human rights system received a total of 978 verified reports over the course of the reporting period and of these, 37 received legal aid support. - In Kenya, a petition co-filed by network member KHRC seeking to halt the implementation of the National Integrated Identity Management System (NIIMS) on grounds that it violated citizen’s right to privacy, amongst other rights, turned out favourably with the High Court in Nairobi ruling to suspend the collection of individuals’ DNA and GPS data as part of the NIIMS registration. Overall the project has reached all target groups including beneficiaries on grass rootlevel in rural areas. The project has reached results towards all 7 objectives, includingengaging dutybearers through evidence based advocacy on the need for responsiveness,public consultations and supportive policies on ICT, human rights and democratic governance.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
